newsitem.title: UK: GOLF-HOLDERS SCOTLAND STUNNED BY INDIA.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-HOLDERS SCOTLAND STUNNED BY INDIA.

text.p: The 1,000-1 outsiders India inflicted a shock 2-1 defeat on holders Scotland as the Scots surrendered their Alfred Dunhill Cup title on Friday.
World number two Colin Montgomerie, crowned European number one last Sunday for the fourth year in succession, lost his second match in two days, this time to a player ranked 696th in the world.

Gaurav Ghei beat him 78-79 on the windblown Old Course at St Andrews, and with Jeev Singh, also ranked 696th, beating Andrew Coltart on the first hole of a playoff, the Indians kept alive their outside chance of advancing to Sunday's playoffs.
They must beat Sweden 3-0 in Saturday's final round robin group match to win their group and reach the semifinals.
"We feel great. We got used to the cold and windy weather and we fought well," Singh said.
"Colin did not have a very good day, and when that happens to a good player anything is possible," Ghei, the Asian Masters champion, said. "I kept the pressure on him."
Montgomerie's round began to go wrong at the sixth when his ball hit a rake and bounded into a bunker up against the lip. He took a triple-bogey seven to fall behind and never fully recovered.
"Ghei played very well and holed out well. When he birdied the first, I knew I was in a match," said Montgomerie, who lost to Swede Jarmo Sandelin on Thursday.
Scotland's defeat brought back the painful memory of their loss to another unfancied team, Paraguay, in the 1993 event.
